item.title: N.Korea Nuclear Talks Seen Delayed to Mid-January (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - Six-country talks to try to halt communist North Korea's nuclear weapons program -- which had been expected this month -- are likely to be put off until mid-January, South Korea's Yonhap news agency reported on Friday.

item.title: Four Israelis Wounded in West Bank Shooting (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - Palestinian gunmen opened fire on an Israeli car near the West Bank city of Nablus early on Friday, wounding four Israelis, military sources said.

item.title: Presumed Qaeda Evidence Frees Hamburg 9/11 Suspect (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - A Moroccan man on trial in Germany for abetting the September 11 attacks was freed on Thursday in the light of secret new evidence, apparently from a captured al Qaeda leader.

item.title: U.S. Signals Flexibility on Iraq Contracts Amid Row (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - President Bush on Thursday rejected criticism of his bar on Iraq war opponents winning lucrative reconstruction contracts, but signaled flexibility as Germany and others demanded a rethink.

item.title: Car Blast Kills Man Near Italian Synagogue (Reuters)
item.description: Reuters - A car exploded in northern Italy early on Thursday, killing the 33-year-old Kuwaiti driver in what police said appeared to be more of a suicide bid rather than an attack on a nearby synagogue.

item.title: Trafalgar Square Has Room for Statue (AP)
item.description: AP - For more than a century, huge stone lions and a statue of Britain's greatest naval hero have surveyed the crowds that swarm through Trafalgar Square.

item.title: AP: Israeli Talks Settlement Withdrawal (AP)
item.description: AP - Israel may soon be compelled to dismantle a "considerable" number of Jewish settlements and draw a border around the rest, Israel's vice premier told The Associated Press on Thursday — a go-it-alone approach he suggested has Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's tacit backing.

item.title: Haitian Police, Student Protesters Clash (AP)
item.description: AP - Police fired tear gas and warning shots Thursday at thousands of students calling for President Jean-Bertrand Aristide's ouster, as four private radio stations shut down because government supporters called in death threats.

item.title: Cardinal Tzauda of Ethiopia Dies at 82 (AP)
item.description: AP - Cardinal Paulos Tzauda, archbishop of Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, for more than 20 years, died Thursday. He was 82.

item.title: U.N. Warns Afghanistan About Warlords (AP)
item.description: AP - The United Nations warned on Thursday that the government's inability to curb the power of warlords and the slow pace of reconstruction are undermining Afghanistan's shaky recovery.

item.title: Martin places Goodale in finance, McLellan as deputy prime minister (Canadian Press)
item.description: Canadian Press - OTTAWA (CP) - In a sweeping change that will put his stamp quickly and firmly on government, Paul Martin is set to unveil a dramatically new cabinet Friday with Ralph Goodale as finance minister and Anne McLellan as deputy prime minister.

item.title: Stranded Pilot Causes Diplomatic Storm (AP)
item.description: AP - What does a man have to do to get a tank of gas in Antarctica?
